Award.AwardTitle: Creating a Minor in Education as a Pathway for Science, Math, or Computer Science Majors to Obtain Teaching Licensure
Award.AbstractNarration: This project aims to serve the national need of preparing highly effective science, math, and computer science teachers for high need middle and secondary schools. It will do this through creation of a new pathway toward teaching licensure for STEM majors. Significant to this project is the realization that many students do not begin college knowing their long-term career aspirations. This project intends to lay the foundation to enable students who decide to become teachers later in their college years to successfully pursue teaching certification without significant additional time to degree. In addition to providing the principal investigators with information they can use to create and submit a Noyce proposal, this Capacity Building project may yield information to encourage similar efforts across Wisconsin and the nation. <br/><br/>This project is a partnership between St. Norbert’s College, a four-year private Catholic Liberal Arts College, and Northeast Wisconsin Technical School (NWTS), a two-year public college that prepares students for careers in science and technology. The project goals include development of: (1) a pathway for geology, physics, mathematics, computer science, environmental science or chemistry majors to obtain an undergraduate minor leading to Wisconsin state education licensure; (2) a general education introductory course that satisfies licensing requirements, with a teaching-focused field experience; (3) a strong partnership with NWTS leading to transfer students matriculating to St. Norbert's College; and (4) strengthening community partnerships to increase the number of qualified STEM teachers. This Capacity Building project proposes to build a pathway to teaching for STEM majors starting at NWTS. In addition to creating a minor in education, the project’s intellectual merit includes the creation of a single class that satisfies general education requirements, provides foundational knowledge on adolescent development requisite for licensure, and provides students with an extensive internship experience to aid them in discerning if STEM teaching is an appropriate career trajectory. The project’s broader impacts include the creation of a model that can be adopted by other institutions for the purpose of providing a low-risk entrance into STEM education experiences. The work will be evaluated through targeted formative and summative evaluation that involves qualitative and quantitative approaches. Work will be disseminated through national, local and regional channels for institutions with similar licensure requirements. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report 

Project title: Creating a Minor in Education as a Pathway for Science, Math, or Computer Science Majors to Obtain Teaching Licensure

Awardee: St. Norbert College

Award Number: 2050457

St. Norbert College (SNC) of De Pere, Wisconsin, partnered with Northeast Wisconsin Technical College (NWTC) and the Green Bay Area Public School District (GBAPS) to develop a STEM teacher preparation program. The overarching goal of the project was to increase the number of students pursuing STEM licensure in the state of Wisconsin. Strategies used to accomplish this goal included: 1. Creation of a 4-12 Teaching major for STEM majors, 2. Identification of several STEM pathways to 4-12 science licensure; 3. Development of an introductory education course (EDUC 103) to be a transition course for students pursuing STEM teacher certification; 3. Development of a strong external partnership with NWTC; and 4. Strengthening existing urban, suburban, and rural community partnerships. A unique aspect of the development of the 4-12 science teacher preparation program is the target audience. It was designed for students who decide to pursue teaching later in their college careers, in particular, SNC students who are recruited into STEM teaching while already completing a STEM major and transfer students from NWTC who completed the Laboratory Science Technology program. 

The Noyce Capacity Building Grant to support the STEM Teacher Education Unique Pathway provided the resources to support development of the partnerships between NWTC and GBAPS and the 4-12 teaching major. The project team met regularly starting in the spring of 2021 through summer of 2021, and occasionally after that time. This collaboration effort resulted in development of a 4-12 teaching major, which will lead to our success in meeting our primary goal of increasing the number of students pursuing STEM teacher preparation  in the state of Wisconsin. The new major was approved by SNC faculty, the SNC Board of Trustees, and HLC.

The design of the STEM teaching pathway rests on completing a double major: 1) 4-12 teaching major; and 2) STEM major. We are currently in the process of seeking approval for SNC?s 4-12 science teacher preparation program by the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction. In terms of developing robust content knowledge - knowing what to teach - candidates are expected to know content taught in 4-12 science classrooms in Wisconsin including: life science; physical science; earth and space science; engineering, technology, and society; science and engineering practices; and cross cutting concepts. We anticipate that school districts around the state will have widely varying science teaching needs. Some administrators may seek science teachers who possess the broadest possible content knowledge across the sciences in order to teach across multiple science disciplines. Other administrators may need content-specific science specialists.  

Thus 4-12 Science candidates at St. Norbert College can choose one of six science-based majors. Each of those six majors falls into one of two pathways. Pathway 1: Rural Teaching Focus includes majors in Environmental Science, Chemistry (biochemistry concentration), Geology, and Natural Sciences. These four majors require coursework in 3 or more distinct science fields, thus offering the broadest content preparation. Candidates interested in teaching in rural schools/districts will be encouraged to select a science major from Pathway 1 as doing so will position them to teach a broad array of middle school and high school science courses. Pathway 2: Suburban/Urban Teaching Focus includes majors in Biology (organismal or biomedical concentration), Chemistry (general chemistry concentration), and Physics (general physics concentration). These four majors require coursework in two distinct science disciplines along with the Natural Science 315: Climate Change course requirement for the 4-12 Teaching major. Candidates interested in developing deeper content knowledge in a single science discipline and teaching in suburban or urban schools/districts will be encouraged to select a major from Pathway 2. They will also be required to take the Praxis II General Science exam to demonstrate breadth of science content knowledge. SNC?s Teacher Education Department awaits the state?s Department of Public Instruction decision to approve this program.

In summary, the resources provided by the Noyce Capacity Building Grant helped investigators and collaborators to build the capacity needed to submit a Track I proposal. Essential elements developed as a direct result of the grant include: 1. Development and approval of the 4-12 teaching major by SNC faculty, the SNC Board of Trustees, and HLC; 2. Development of a 4-12 science licensure proposal to submit to the state of Wisconsin; 3. Development of marketing ideas for recruitment of scholars to participate in the proposed program; 4. Development of math and science methods courses as well as a new transition education course.
